Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides three years of funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Wabash Seminar and Miniconference." The three seminar meetings in the first year of the award will be held on October 24, 2015, February 27, 2016, and April 9, 2016, on the campus of Wabash College, while the 2015 miniconference will be held September 12-13, 2015, on the campus of the Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI). Additional information is available on the seminar web site http://www.math.purdue.edu/~mdd/Wabash/

The Wabash seminar and miniconference series, which is organized by a consortium of Midwestern mathematics departments, has for over forty years provided a catalyst for the stimulation and dissemination of significant contributions to a wide range of areas of modern analysis, with a primary focus on functional and harmonic analysis. The format for Wabash events provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual Miniconference and the regular Wabash seminars for Operator Algebras started at Wabash College, Indiana in the 1970s. In 2015, NSF grant funding supported this important scholarly activity for three years. The support has then been extended for another additional two years, until May 2020.

 

During 2015-2020 the annual Miniconference and the regular Wabash seminars attracted a total of 144 participants. Among them, there are 62 faculty (including 5 women faculty), 27 postdocs (including 2 women and 3 underrepresented), 50 graduate students (including 11 women and 4 underrepresented), and 4 undergraduate students (a small number of participants appear as both students/postdocs, respectively postdocs/faculty during this five year span). There are 20 women and 7 underrepresented participants.

 

In the fifth year, a significant effort was put on inviting postdocs, graduate students and undergraduate students to disseminate significant research contributions. Out of the 12 invited talks, 5 have been given by postdocs and 2 by graduate students. We also had 6 20 minute talks given by our graduate students at the Miniconference.  Three undergraduate students (two from UIUC and one from Purdue) were invited to present their operator algebras related research results in two 20 minute talks in the Miniconference. Two of these students will start graduate programs in Mathematics in Fall 2020 at UT Austin and respectively Cambridge (UK). This is a very good start to reach out to undergraduate students. More undergraduate students are encouraged to attend Wabash activities. 

 

Participants from 50 institutions have attended the activities supported by this grant. In addition to the four participating universities (UIUC, Purdue, IU, IUPUI), there were participants from 48 other institutions in the United States (Washington University St. Louis, Texas A&M, Ohio State, Penn State, Vanderbilt, U.C. Berkeley, U.C.L.A., Arizona State, University of Colorado Boulder, University of Minnesota, University of Cincinnati, Miami University, Ohio University, Northern Illinois University, Southern Illinois University, University of Houston, University of Washington, Baylor University, University of Hawaii, Northwestern, Caltech, University of Florida, University of Virginia, Dartmouth College, U.C. Riverside, U.T. San Antonio, University of Puerto Rico, Michigan State, DePaul, Adrian College, University of Arkansas).

Among 144 participants in five years, 26 are from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 20 from Purdue University, 14 IU Bloomington, 12 IUPUI, 7 Washington University St. Louis,  7 from Texas A & M, 4 from Ohio State, 4 Penn State, and 4 Vanderbilt.

International participants from research institutions with tradition in operator algebras and operator theory in the following 10 countries have also attended: Canada, U.K., Poland, Germany, Spain, Romania, Israel, Japan, Australia, China, as follows:  Canada (University of Toronto, University of Waterloo,

York University, McGill, University of Saskatchewan, University of Manitoba), U.K. (University of Glasgow, Cardiff University), Poland (Institute of Mathematics Polish Academy, University of Warsaw), Spain (Universidad Complutense de Madrid /ICMAT), Romania (Institute of Mathematics Romanian Academy), Israel (Technion), Japan (Kyoto University), Australia (University of Adelaide, University of New South Wales), and China (East China Normal University).

 Evidently, the impact of the annual Miniconference and the regular Wabash seminars went beyond the Midwest region. It has also reached out to other parts of the United States and the world.
